importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, at Hong Kong International Airport, marking a significant aviation safety event in the region.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The cargo plane skidded off the runway at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, which is a critical time point for determining the sequence of events and response actions.

keyTakeAways: A Boeing aircraft operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) after landing from Dubai.
The plane broke in two upon impact and collided with an airport security patrol car, resulting in the deaths of two staff members.
The aircraft was partially submerged with significant structural damage, including the tail section being snapped off and front section below the cockpit damaged.
All four crew members were treated at local hospitals and reported to be safe; no cargo was on board.
The aircraft did not emit distress signals during approach, and no emergency requests were received from pilots.
Hong Kong International Airport suspended operations on its north runway to facilitate removal of the aircraft, though operations on the other two runways continue.
The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, where fatal aviation accidents are rare, highlighting the severity of the event.
The flight was operated under an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides extra cargo capacity to major carriers.
More than 200 people, fire engines, and boats were involved in the emergency response, indicating a large-scale coordination effort.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) after landing from Dubai at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time. The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact and collided with an airport security patrol car, killing two staff members. Despite no distress signals from the pilots, the aircraft was left partially submerged with significant structural damage, and all four crew members were treated and released. The airport suspended operations on its north runway for safety and removal efforts, though other runways remain operational. The flight was under an Emirates flight number, but the aircraft was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major carriers. This incident marks a rare but serious event at one of the world’s busiest and safest airports, with historical context from a 1999 crash at the same airport providing a backdrop of aviation risk at HKIA.
title: Two Killed as Cargo Plane Skids Off Runway into the Sea in Hong Kong
